key_points: John Griffin, a former CNN producer, has been indicted on charges of luring young girls to his Vermont ski house for "sexual subservience" training.
Griffin used messaging apps to persuade mothers to allow him to "train" their daughters sexually.
At least one mother was convinced to bring her 13-year-old daughter to Griffin's ski house in June 2020.
Griffin paid $3,000 for plane tickets for the mother and daughter to travel from Nevada to Boston, where he picked them up.
Authorities allege the daughter was forced to engage in unlawful sexual activity at Griffin's ski house.
Griffin attempted to entice two other children over the internet into sexual activity using apps like Kik and Google Hangout.
The indictment mentions a "virtual training session" Griffin suggested over video chat for a mother and her 14-year-old daughter.
Griffin boasts of working "shoulder to shoulder" with Chris Cuomo on LinkedIn and has worked at CNN for almost nine years.
The government seeks to seize Griffin's property, including his Ludlow ski house and his Tesla, used in the alleged crimes.
Griffin faces a mandatory minimum of 10 years in jail on each count if convicted.
